titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI:30. Wednesday. W. S. Smith came this morning, and told me that he proposed to apply for an appointment abroad— For the first vacancy as Secretary of Legation; and enquired if I should oppose his appointment. I told him that if my opinion was asked, I should give it, and should feel myself compelled to state facts relating to the demand which he made upon his return from Europe, for which I referred him to Mr Pleasonton; advising him to compare the receipt which he gave me at Paris 22 March 1815, with the charge which he made after his return to this Country, and of which he received payment— Mrs Poindexter called to see Mrs Adams upon which Smith went away to call at Pleasonton’s Office— At the President’s I found him in his Cabinet; the first time since his illness. At the Office I had visits from Messrs:Pitkin, Hawkins, Cathcart and R. King— Pitkin and King came to converse with me upon the Bills in contemplation relating to Colonial trade, and Navigation. Pitkin read me the draft of a Bill proposed by General S. Smith, for a total repeal of discriminating duties without conditioning for our admission to the Colonies of the European Powers in return. I told him what had passed between ten Cate and me, on this subject. He thought Smith’s Bill went too far, and that the measures proposed in my Report on the Netherland Negotiation would be sufficient— Mr Hawkins came with a Letter from Mr T. Claiborne Chairman of a Committee of the House of Representatives on the Ghent Treaty Commission calling upon him for an account of the expenditures of the Commission under the 6th. and 7th. Articles, and his opinion upon their principle— Hawkins asked my opinion what he was to do— The field of enquiry he said was so wide that he scarcely knew how to answer the Letter— I advised him to go before the Committee, and give such explanations as they might ask— Cathcart came about some old claims of his own, and to plead his merits in our public transactions with Algiers; as to his claims I told him Congress was the only competent authority now for admitting them— Mr King told me the Committee of Foreign Relations of the Senate, had reported a Bill to prohibit the admission of any British vessels into the Ports of the United States, from any Port into which the vessels of the United States are not admitted— Calhoun called and took the last despatch from Mr Gallatin. My wife spent the Evening at her Sister Frye’s.

2. VI: At the President’s. He is yet convalescent. Visits at the Office from J. M. Baker, to renew his application for an Office abroad— It is now the Consulate of Tunis—or any thing else: from Reynolds applying to be appointed keeper of the Public Building in which the Offices of the State, War and Navy Departments are kept. From Mr Phillebroun a Clerk in the War Office, to recommend a newspaper Printer of the U.S. Laws at Hallowell in the District of Maine. From Mr Force, a person who has advertised proposals for publishing here an American Quarterly Review, and who came to ask for my Assistance in carrying it on, which while holding my present Office, is impossible. Mr Middleton had papers relating to a claim on the Spanish Government in Florida, which he left with me with a request that I would write about them to Mr Onis. We had a company of Gentlemen to dinner. MessrsG. W. Campbell, Clay,Crittenden,Desha,Fromentin,Garnett,Genl. Harrison,Holley,Johnson,Macon,Poindexter,Pope,Ringgold,Robertson of Louisiana, Silsbee,Speed,Storer, and Tait— Messrs:Eppes and Newton declined from indisposition, and MessrsHay, and Troup, who have left the City. They went away about nine O’Clock.

3. V:45. Morning visitors, Mr Walsh, who spoke to me of a late speech of Hopkinson’s in the House of Representatives. I told him I had set down Hopkinson as henceforth an antagonist to the Administration. Walsh said it was not so. He thought Hopkinson had been right, on the principle; I thought him fundamentally wrong. He says Mr Hay attacked Hopkinson about that speech, at a dinner table, two or three days since, and Hopkinson answered him not at all to his satisfaction. Mr Holmes was here to enquire about his compensation as a Commissioner under the fourth Article of the Treaty of Ghent. I told him what the arrangements had been, upon the Commissions under the Treaty of 1794; but that the President had not come to a decision in the present case. Mr O’Sullivan came again to renew his application for a Consular Appointment, at Tunis or at Buenos Ayres. The President has determined not to give him either. I did
not call this Morning at the President’s— My visitors at the Office, were a Mr F. Adams of Alexandria, to solicit the appointment of Consul at Marseilles. Mr Crowell the delegate from the Alabama Territory, who goes away before the end of the Session of Congress, Dr Blake, who brought an application to the President for the appointment of three additional magistrates at Alexandria; and Mr Blagrove who came for an order for the payment of Clerk hire for making out a list of prisoners taken during the late war, to be transmitted to Mr Bagot for the British Government. Blagrove wanted an order for payment a Month in advance which he said had been done before; but which I refused— We had an Evening party at our house— Mr Baker the English Consul General challenged me to a game of Chess— Mr Clay returned me the Letter from Hughes which I had yesterday given him to read, and urged strongly that Hughes might be appointed to another Mission. The day was very warm, and the first verdure is appearing on the fields and trees.

4. VI: At the President’s, he mentioned to me, his intentions in respect to the nominations to be made before the close of the present Session of the Senate, for the foreign Missions— He proposes to send two Commissioners to Constantinople; Mr William Lowndes, the present Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, and Genl. S. Smith of Baltimore; with powers to negotiate a Treaty. Mr Lowndes to remain there, and General Smith to return by the way of Naples and make a further attempt to negotiate for the claims upon that Government which were the object of Mr W. Pinkney’s Mission. For the mission to Russia, he proposes to nominate G. W. Campbell, now a Senator from Tennessee— He said he did not approve the principle of appointing Members of Congress to foreign Missions, but as it had been established in practice from the first organization of the present Government, and as the members of Congress would not be satisfied with the opposite principle, he did not think proper to make it a rule for himself. He asked my opinion of the persons he had mentioned, and I gave it freely, notwithstanding the delicacy and difficulty of the task— The President spoke of his desire to appoint some person from the Western Country to one of the highest Offices of the Government. He had informed Mr Clay of his intention to appoint me Secretary of State, and had offered him the War Department which he declined. He had also consulted him as to his disposition, whether he would accept the Mission to England; which he had also repelled; observing that he was satisfied with the situation which he held, and could render more service to the public than in the other situations offered him— The War Department had then offered to Governor Shelby of Kentucky, at the urgent recommendation of Coll. R. M. Johnson, who had expressed the opinion that he would accept it; but he declined on account of his age, his habits and a determination that he had taken not to engage again in the public service. Since then no character belonging to the Western Country had occurred with stronger claims to distinction than G. W. Campbell— There were indeed General JacksonGeneral Harrison and Coll. R. M. Johnson, all of whom might have claims; but he thought none of them ought to prevail over those of Mr Campbell— He passed in review the principal States of the Union; observed that Massachusetts had had its share of the late Diplomatic appointments— That there was no prominent character in New-York; except Mr King, who probably would not incline to go abroad again; who had already received a full portion of the honours of this description, and who now filled a station of usefulness and honour, in which he was highly distinguished— I asked him whether the present Governor of New-York had occurred to him, as a person suitable for a foreign Mission— He looked surprized, but said the Governor of New-York certainly was a very prominent character; but he believed his views were not to a mission abroad— He would probably not accept one if it should be offered— Pennsylvania he said had already two of the Missions, and Mr Gallatin did not now appear to be inclined to return home— So that as he was not for the present inclined to bring forward any Virginian; he thought the new Missions ought to be filled from the South and the West. I gave him my opinion with the utmost freedom; and perfect confidence, concerning all the persons whom he had mentioned— With respect to Mr Eustis and Mr Russell he was very determined they should come home. Eustis’s state of health, rendered it advisable; and as to Russell he had received as much notice and distinction from the Government, as the public opinion of the Country would tolerate; Mr Madison had with extreme reluctance consented to his last return to Sweden, and at the earnest solicitation of Mr Clay— He the President had acquiesced in it; but the only public object to be accomplished by it was the completion of the Negotiation of the Commercial Treaty, which could not take more than a Month or two of time— But Mr Russell instead of going directly to Stockholm his destination, had been amusing himself at London and Paris, and indulging his taste for traveling at the public expence— It was time this should cease, and he directed me to write to Mr Russell, informing him very explicityly that his mission there must terminate
in the course of the present year. At the Office, Mr Ten Cate, sent me a certificate under his official seal that he had appointed Don Diego Morphy, now acting as Spanish Vice-Consul at New Orleans, to be the Consular Agent of the Netherlands, there in the room of another person whom he removed. I found no record in the Office that this person had ever been appointed. I sent and requested ten Cate to come to the Office; and he immediately came. I told him the regular manner in which he should communicate to me his appointment of Mr Morphy, upon which an exequatur would issue, and be sent to him— I mentioned also that Mr Morphy was no longer acting as Spanish Vice-Consul at New-Orleans. He took back his certificate and said he would send me a notification in due form: but it would be too late to send as he had intended by Mr Noëli who was going off this day for New-Orleans. Mr Ten Cate then entered at large into Conversation with me, on the subject of the late abortive Negotiation, at The Hague, and the revocation of the discriminating duties. He recapitulated what had passed between us heretofore, for the purpose he said of making with more certainty a correct report of it to his Government, and he took the opportunity to sound further what we should be disposed to do, if the Negotiation should be resumed. He left me, apparently not dissatisfied— Mrs Adams called for me at the Office at 5 O’Clock; and after leaving Mary Hellen at her Mother’s we went and dined at Mr Middleton’s at Georgetown. Mr and Miss Crowninshield, Judge Johnson of Louisiana, Mr. and Mrs G. W. Campbell, Genl. Dickerson, and Genl. and Mrs Ringgold were there— The weather having been foul, the roads were bad— Our Carriage in coming for us in the Evening was overset; the harness broken, and the boy Philip, took a sprain in the side so that we were obliged to take him home in the Carriage. We got home with difficulty; being twice on the point of oversetting, and at the Treasury-Office Corner, we were both obliged to get out of the Carriage in the mud. I called out the guard of the Treasury-Office, and borrowed a lanthorn with which we came home— We immediately sent for the surgeon nearest at hand who came and bled Philip— It was a mercy that we all got home with whole bones.

5. VI:30. The boy was not essentially hurt yesterday, and this day, was quite well again. I attended Church at the Capitol, and heard Mr Holley again— His discourse was rather a lecture than a Sermon; and was not so long, as that of last Sunday. He opened his doctrines more fully, and his argument bore upon two very distinct points. one was to urge mutual and universal toleration—and the other was upon the poetical imagery, or what he termed expressly the mythology of the Bible. He drew a parallel between the Fables of Chronos, Ouranon and Gee, Jupiter, Neptune and Pluto, and Cupid and Psyche, and the six days of the Creation—the Creation of the woman from the rib of man, and the Serpent the tree of knowledge and the fatal apple. He explained the exoteric and the esoteric meanings of these passages of scripture, and pronounced the fable of Saturn’s devouring his own children equally true, with the narratives in the Book of Genesis. I could scarcely sit and hear him with Patience. The house was full— I returned immediately home. W. S. Smith came to attempt explanations of his receipt of 22 March 1815 given to me at Paris, and of his account at the Treasury. He could not account for how it happened— We were interrupted by a visit from Mr and Mrs Chevallié; after which I had a long one, from Coll. Forbes, who informed me he had lately come from Amelia-Island, and whom much to my surprize I found to be James Forbes, brother of the Consul at Copenhagen. I had seen the name of Forbes among those of the mock legislature of the Florida’s at Fernandina, but without imagining that it was he. Without explicitly informing me how, or when he went there, or for what purpose he gave me to understand that he had been there most if not all the time from M’Gregor’s taking the island, until possession was taken of it by Captain Henley and Major Bankhead. He gave me many particulars, of the proceedings of the sham patriots under M’Gregor and Aury, and of the characters of the men, confirming everything that has been said of their profligacy— He says that the Mexican Congress was a vessel bought by Mina at Baltimore, then called the Calypso; and that Aury contrived to get her from Mina, without paying for her— That Aury was originally a French Sail-maker—afterwards a Sailor, and lived in St. Domingo; till in 1813 he went
and offered his services to the Patriots of New-Grenada, who gave him a Commission, as Lieutenant in their Navy. He is a man entirely illiterate and ignorant; and his papers were written by Dr Gual; and by a young man named Comte, who was born at Baltimore, and educated at the Jesuits College there. Son of a St. Domingo refugee not more than twenty years old— Of some abilities, but habitually addicted to intoxication. Gual was the most respectable man among them; but in desperate circumstances and having no means of subsistence— He went there from New-York in the America Libre, in September last, and took Pazos with him— Pazos was a Printer at Buenos-Ayres, banished by the Supreme Director Pueyrredon. Murden was a South-Carolinian, ignorant and worthless. Irwin though a member of the last Congress, nothing better. Mabrity a Spanish South-American speaking no other language. Aury had not more than forty Saint Domingo blacks with him; his recruiting there having been stopped short. They were constantly for some time on the point of bloodshed between the French and American parties which were so equally balanced that in their pretended legislature they were four and four; and he Forbes would have been the ninth, if he had accepted; but had declined. A number of prizes had been brought in by Aury’s prizes, but by his bad management he had got nothing by them— Heath had been the judge of Admiralty under M’Gregor, but he resigned, and after Aury came he made Rousselin the judge, who had been the collector of the Customs at Galveston— Forbes made some enquiry, if I had lately heard from his brother at Copenhagen; he had mentioned his distressed situation there, by the insufficiency of his Salary— I attempted to write after dinner this Evening; but from rhumatic pains was soon obliged to desist.

6. V:30.Cardelli the Sculptor came this morning to say that he had given the Bust of Coll: Trumbull, which has been at my house, till now to Mr Latrobe who would send here for it— Cardelli says he is now working at the Capitol upon leaves and ornaments; which gives him bread, but no reputation. Latrobe himself came to ask for the bust. He told me that he had the character of being the most extravagant Architect in the United States, though he is in reality the most economical— I was but a short time at the President’s. At the Office I had visits from Mr Schee, a Solicitor for the Office of Consul at Genoa, and from General P. B. Porter, who is much affected by the manner in which the House of Representatives are scrutinizing the expences of the Ghent Treaty Commissions— He had been before the select Committee this Morning, and from their questions had found they had suspicions that he had projects of Speculation upon the Lands on the St. Lawrence, which the Commissioners are surveying; he said it was an infamous calumny. He is going away and wants an advance of money— Mr Brent was absent from the Office on Saturday, for indisposition, and this day left it at three O’Clock— Mrs Adams attended a Ball at Mr Bagot’s, and came home with Mr and Mrs Crawford.

7. VI:30. A Mr Charles came to solicit a Subscription for a work he is undertaking; an American Ornithology, to be in ten quarto Volumes with coloured plates, and I subscribed. At the President’s I met Mr Crawford, and Mr Crowninshield— The translations of the Letters from Pueyrredon the Supreme Director of the United Provinces of La Plata to the President, and of Mr Aquirre to me were read— At the Office, Mr Antrobus came from Mr Bagot, with an exemplification of an act of the Legislature of Nova-Scotia, repealing a Law previously enacted relating to the trade in Plaster of Paris; and to counteract which an Act of Congress passed at the last Session. Mr Antrobus left the exemplification of the Nova-Scotia repealing Act with me to be copied. I asked him if Mr Bagot wished any measure to be taken upon it on our part. He said no, he was directed only to make the Communication— Mr Brent who continues much indisposed was again absent this day from the Office, and by his absence the accumulation of business, increases, and falls more and more into confusion— There were about half a dozen new Calls from members of Congress, for Documents, papers, Volumes of the Laws, and other merely teazing applications, wasting time to little or no purpose. When I got home to dinner I found a Note from T. Claiborne, asking further explanations of the answer which I sent to his last Note, and an Answer to-morrow Morning. There was an Evening party at Mr Tayloe’s to which we were invited, which we did not attend—

8. VI: There was this Morning a heavy thunder shower, and the rain continued the greater part of the day. I called at Pleasonton’s Office and examined the Accounts of the Commissioners for ascertaining the St. Croix river, under the Treaty of November 1794— Also at Mr Crawford’s to mention to him the application from Mr Bagot, for the admission of British vessels from Turks Island, and the Bahama’s. At the President’s he spoke to me again of the projected missions to Constantinople and to Russia— He said Mr Crawford had suggested a doubt, whether it would be advisable to appoint more than one Minister for the Turkish Mission; and that both Crawford and
Calhoun, thought G. W. Campbell, preferable to either Jackson, Harrison or Johnson for the Mission to Russia. He said he had also spoken confidentially of Mr Campbell to the two Senators from Pennsylvania, with both of whom he the President had long been intimate; and who though plain men, were sound and judicious men. Both approved and strongly urged the appointment of Campbell— He said also that when in Virginia last Autumn, he had enquired of Mr Jefferson, how it would suit to appoint Genl. Jackson to the Russian Mission— His answer was; why, Good God! he would breed you a quarrel, before he had been there a Month! I told the President that as the other persons whom he had consulted personally knew all the characters much better than I did, I should press no further the objection to Mr Campbell— The President said that there was another difficulty in the way of appointing Jackson. He was second in command, and such a distinction conferred upon him, might seem an undue preference shewn him over his superior Officer, Brown. But as it would not be in the military line, I did not think much of that. At the Office Mr Brent was still absent, indisposed— I was engaged until near five O’Clock in examining the Journals of the St Croix river Commission, and answering Mr T. Claiborne’s Letter of last Evening. I had written him a note this morning, to say I would send him an answer in the course of the day. But Claiborne went off this morning to Philadelphia, and Mr Philip P. Barbour is now the Chairman of the Committee, from whom when I came home this Evening, I found a Letter asking for more information respecting the execution of the Commissions under the fourth and fifth Articles of the Treaty of Ghent. There was a Drawing Room this Evening at the President’s, which we did not attend, for want of a Carriage, our Harness being irreparable.

9. VI:Mr Force came to solicit assistance for an American Quarterly Review, which he proposes to publish, and concerning which he has written to me, and called at the office before. I have not leisure to give him the aid he wants. Mr Walsh was here, and offered to write a pamphlet upon South-American affairs, examining the subject to the bottom. But he wants employment which I have not the means of giving him. He is one of the ablest political writers in this Country; but his opinions originally took a lurch from which he has not and it is doubtful whether he ever will recover. And as he has justly great confidence in himself, he would be a dangerous auxiliary. He would write only in his own views, and upon principles many of which are not those of the President, or of any part of his Administration. His support might therefore do more harm than good. He expressed a desire this Morning to be appointed as Editor of the secret Journals of the Old Congress, which by a Resolution of the present Session are to be published; asked if any compensation would be allowed for making the selection, and said it would be a very pleasant occupation. He hinted that he would speak of it to the President. I called again at Pleasonton’s Office, and at Mr Crawford’s. Examined the Accounts of the Commission under the 4th: Article of the Ghent Treaty— Met Coll. Forbes there, who gave some further particulars respecting the Affairs of Amelia-Island— Lavignac he says was a Frenchman who went from Baltimore, and Chapelle an American from Connecticut, understanding neither French nor Spanish— He told me Pazos had yesterday shown him the supplementary Documents published relating to Amelia-Island, and that in the papers furnished by Pazos there were many incorrect statements. He said he went there himself shortly after the death of Hubbard. At the Office, I wrote an answer to Mr P. P. Barbour successor to Mr Claiborne, as Chairman of the Ghent-Treaty-Commissions Committee— Mr D. Brent attended though yet imperfectly recovered from his indisposition. T. Johnston came to solicit an advance of 500 Dollars to enable him to go to Holland in pursuit of a claim upon the Government of the Netherlands— He was two years ago appointed Consul at Calais, to aid him in the pursuit of this claim, but never repaired to his Post. I told him the controul of the President over public money was very limited and that the advance which he requested could not be made. He talked of the desperation of his Circumstances, and a starving family of children. It is very difficult to resist such applications as this; but in the public service, and especially in the care of public monies, it seems as if one were required to have a heart of stone. I could reply nothing to this man’s tale of distress, but I remained inflexible. He asked me, if in case he should obtain from private resources the means of going to Europe, I would give him instructions
to our Ministers in France, and the Netherlands, to befriend him in urging his claim— I promised him I would. Mr Silsbee came, and left the Statement of his demand upon the money obtained by Decatur at Algiers, with his vouchers. He insists that another claimant, a man named Smith, of Philadelphia, has received too much; and he with the other claimants whose powers he has, not only asks all the remainder of the money, but insists upon reserving a claim for more. I took his papers to obtain the President’s directions concerning them. Mr G. Peter, a member of Congress came with a young man named Dunlop, who applies for the appointment of Secretary to the Alabama Territory; and who brought with him several recommendations. Mrs Adams went out again this day, but our horses have become so vicious that it is impossible to drive them in the Carriage. Evening at home, writing.

10. VI: At the President’s this Morning, I met Mr Crawford and Mr Wirt. There was some Conversation upon the claim of Mr Silsbee and others for the Algerine Money. Crawford was for huffing the demand, and refusing to be teazed about it— Crawford would not act so in his own Department; but such are the mazes of the human heart. This is not the first time, I have seen the drift of Crawford’s advice— While he is assiduously making friends to himself, he has no objection to my making as many enemies to myself as circumstances will admit; he has not pursued this course so far as Clay; who with all his ardour urged the President to let Russell go back to Sweden, as Minister, and now in his last Speech for the Buenos-Ayres appropriation blames the administration for keeping Ministers at Stockholm, and in the Netherlands— I left Silsbee’s papers with the President and asked him to give me directions with regard to the payment of the remaining money; having some doubt of my authority to pay it out. The President asked me to call again as I returned home from the Office— Asbury Dickins a Clerk in the Treasury Department brought me yesterday a draft of a Memorial to Congress proposed to be signed by all the Clerks, asking for an increase of their Salaries— He said Mr Crawford had suggested to him the propriety of adding a paragraph stating that the Memorial had been submitted to the heads of Departments and had their approbation— I thought there should be some discrimination— That some of the Clerks were sufficiently paid, and others were not— But Mr Crawford thought no discrimination necessary, and I consented to the addition of the paragraph, if agreed to by the other Heads of Departments— Captain Riley came and took leave, intending to go for New-York to-morrow. He asked for a copy of O’Sullivan’s answer to his Letter of charges— I declined giving it, as it was merely a defence of himself and contained no charges against Riley— On returning to the President’s, I found he had this morning offered to Mr William Lowndes, the choice of a Mission to Constantinople or to Russia. He shewed me his answer, declining both. And he said as Congress appeared to be getting into a querulous humour, about the foreign Missions, and as he knew no other person whose nomination would carry the same weight in its favour, he inclined rather to postpone any nomination to Constantinople for the present. I told him that I had intended this morning, to suggest to his Consideration the propriety of postponing the measure: which upon the perusal of a Memoir which had been furnished by General S. Smith, I had concluded would be most expedient— The President again expressed his conviction that G. W. Campbell would be the most eligible Western man, to send to Russia. I told him I should press no farther any objection against him— The President told me he had been astonished, at Mr Clay’s attack upon the administration, for the Swedish Mission, Mr Clay having himself been the cause of Russell’s going back— Russell had come home with a sort of avowed determination not to go back— But he first through Clay, solicited some employment at home, and finding that was not attainable he then was anxious to go back, and Mr Clay became again his solicitor, on the ground that he was the only member of the Ghent Commission, who had not been specially noticed by distinction; and as there was to be further negotiation about the Treaty that Russell had made with Sweden, Mr Madison consented that he should go back for that service— This Evening I drafted a Note to Onis, on the papers left with me by Mr Middleton.

11. V:45. At the President’s met Mr Crowninshield. Had less interruption than usual at the Office. Drafted Reports, and Letters— Spent the Evening at Mr Hyde de Neuville’s, the French Minister— There I learnt that the House of Representatives this day passed the Counter-Navigation Bill; which had already passed the Senate with only two dissentient votes. The Majority in the House of Representatives was also very great— I found in speaking of it to Mr Bagot that he felt it more keenly than I had expected he would. He said he might now, after the measure was fixed, say that he thought it would not be well received in England— That it would touch their pride, and make them adhere more stiffly to their system— I told him that Pride was apt to act and counteract, and perhaps might influence us too. But that no Government in the world understood better than the British, how to accommodate their pride to
their interests— He said he was fully convinced his Government understood every thing, as well as any other. I also spoke to him of the late repealing Nova-Scotia Plaster Law, and he promised to send a copy of the Law that was repealed. He mentioned the discriminating duties against rolled iron, and the President’s recommendation for their repeal— He was afraid that in the hurry of business at the close of the Session, it would be passed over as it had already been at the last Session— I spoke about it to Mr Lowndes the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and means, who appeared somewhat lukewarm concerning it, and made a question of it as to the right. I played two games of Chess with Dr Tucker, the Treasurer.

12. V:45. My eldest Son, George, is this day seventeen; his mother received a Letter from him at Cambridge, where he entered the Freshman Class, at the close of the Winter vacation. I went to the Congress Hall to attend the service, but there was none performed there— I went to the Presbyterian Church, at the foot of the Capitol Hill, and heard there a Mr Clarke. Mr Southard a member of Congress from New Jersey was there just returned from a visit home— He introduced to me as we were walking from the Church his Colleague Mr Bennett. I rode over to Georgetown and called upon Mr King at the Union Tavern. Had a long conversation with him upon various topics of public affairs— Mrs Adams spent the Evening at her Sister Frye’s.

13. V:30.General P. B. Porter was here, concerning his accounts as Commissioner, under the 6th: and 7th. Articles of the Treaty of Ghent. Mr N. Pope was also here, and I walked with him to the Hall of Congress, and had some conversation with Mr Crittenden a Senator from Kentucky, upon an Act of the Legislature of that State constituting a Company for improving the Navigation of the Ohio at Louisville— A right is reserved for the general Government to subscribe 500 shares to this Company—and the Chairman of the Company enclosed to me a copy of the Act, with the intimation of a wish that Congress might act upon it as soon as possible— The President asked me to see one of the Kentucky Senators and consult with him what should be done about it. Mr Crittenden said the members from that State in both houses of Congress had received similar copies of the Act, but had concluded that it would be best to wait till the next Session before moving the subject in Congress— I found at the Senate Mr S. W. Dana, now a Senator from the State of Connecticut— I stopped about two hours and heard the debates in the Senate; one of which was on a Bill for admitting the Illinois territory into the Union as a State— It is within a few days of ten years since I left this body of which I had been five years a member. Mr Gaillard, of South-Carolina, is the only member now who was a member then— On calling at the President’s, I found he was going out to ride, and I did not stop— I called again as I was returning from the Office. He was at dinner, but saw me for a moment in his Drawing-Room. He told me, Mr G. W. Campbell would go to Russia. Mrs Adams was bled this morning. In the Evening I wrote a Letter, and part of one to my brother.

14. VI: The Letter to my brother insensibly absorbed the morning, till Mr Onis called upon me at my house, and kept me more than two hours in Conversation, upon the state of Affairs between the United States and Spain. He is about to send of Mr Pizarro, one of the persons attached to the Mission, to Spain, to ask for new Instructions, and offered to forward by him any Instructions for Mr Erving. He said he had only two days since received the leave of absence which he had been long soliciting: but he was instructed not to use it, until the negotiation for settling the differences between the two Countries, should be concluded; an event for which the king was extremely solicitous— It would give him extreme satisfaction if he could be so happy as to conclude the Treaty and he wished very much that a close alliance might be formed between the United States and Spain— But if the President thought the Treaty might with more advantage be accomplished at Madrid; he for his part, should very cheerfully acquiesce in that arrangement— I told him, it would be equally satisfactory, to the President, if the arrangement could be made either here or at Madrid; but that he thought it utterly useless either to write or to talk any more, upon the subject; as there never had been a negotiation so completely
exhausted, and upon which there was so little prospect that the parties would ever come to an understanding with each other— He said he did not see why they should not; that he hoped we should ultimately yield something; that he wanted an Alliance between the United States and Spain. That Spain would grant us commercial advantages, and especially any thing that would counteract the commercial tyranny of England. He said I had opened his eyes upon the conduct of England towards Spain, which was full of duplicity. I might be assured that Spain had not asked the Mediation of England to settle her differences with us. Spain had made a statement to England of the state of affairs between her, and us— She had informed England that the king had made up his mind, to cede the Floridas to us and asked the acquiescence of England in the measure; having had previous engagements with England not to cede any territories in America— England instead of agreeing to the proposed cession, offered her mediation, and left it at the option of Spain whether it should be offered here by him, Onis, or by Mr Bagot— He spoke with no small bitterness of England, and of her project of mediation in the affairs of the Colonies. Said he hoped Spain would settle the affair with the Colonists themselves and without intervention of any Mediators; and that if the United States would do any thing to come to an arrangement, Spain would secure to them commercial advantages, which it was evident England wanted to engross exclusively to herself. But with all these Professions Mr Onis proposed nothing, and pretended that the Spanish Government had always supposed the river Colorado, which we had offered to take for the boundary was the red River of Natchitoches, and never imagined it was the Colorado of Texas; which they called the river of St. Bernard— I told him that this mistake was very extraordinary as the boundary in dispute was to commence from the gulph of Mexico, and as we knew of no maps in which the red river of Natchitoches was called Colorado— Its French name being Rouge and its Spanish name Roxo— He said Colorado was the Spanish word for red, and that the river of Natchitoches falling into the Mississippi fell indirectly into the gulph of Mexico— I told Mr Onis that I would write to Mr Erving, by his Messenger— At the President’s I met Mr Calhoun— At the Office I had visits from Mr Kemper and Mr Cathcart, upon their respective claims against this Government, and from Mr Bagot who brought a copy of the Law of the Province of Nova-Scotia, lately repealed— I had a company of Gentlemen at dinner. Messrs:Jas: Barbour, Brent, Burrill, Culbreth, C. Cutts, Daggett, Forsyth, Hale, Horsey, Hubbard, Hunter, Morton, Moseley, Pitkin, Reed, W. Smith, Stokes and Van Dyke. Mr Tallmadge was invited, and sent for excuse that he must leave the city this day. And a card was sent to Mr Morrow, but he neither answered it nor came— Probably he did not receive it— Mrs Adams did not dine with us. It was past six O’Clock before the House of Representatives adjourned, and almost seven, when part of our company came. They went away immediately after dinner.

15. VI:General P. B. Porter, came to the Office to obtain payment of a balence due on account rendered by him at the Treasury, but not settled; and a further advance of 5000 dollars, upon which I chose to take the President’s directions— I called twice at his house; the first time, he was out, and the second, dressing for dinner. I saw him however, and the direction he gave me was to make the advance requested by Genl. Porter. I dined at the President’s with the President of the Senate, the Speaker of the House the Heads of Departments and several Members of both houses of Congress. Immediately after dinner I returned home, and went with Mrs Adams and spent the Evening at Mr Walsh’s, where there was a party of Ladies and Gentlemen. Mr. Van Ness came this morning to the Office, and said the Report of the Committee on the Ghent Treaty Commissions contained a vague and unwarranted censure upon his brother the Commissioner under the fifth Article, which was the more unexpected as the Committee had told him they intended not to make any investigation of the proceedings under that Commission, concerning which there had been no complaint— Van Ness enquired if there had been any complaint against his brother at this Department— There had been none. He said he had ascertained there had been something in a Letter to Mr Holmes, but he did not know from whom. He intimated some suspicion that it was from J. T. Austin, because he had been a candidate for the appointment of agent under the 5th. Article— But I told him I thought that very improbable; as it was a surveyor who would naturally be appointed as agent under the 5th. Article, while Austin was merely a practising lawyer. Van-Ness said he must have been mistaken in his suspicions. This Evening at Walsh’s I asked Mr Onis, when he should despatch his Messenger; I told him I would write by him. He said next Monday or Tuesday; or perhaps some days later— But he promised to give me a day’s notice, before his departure.

16. VII:Mr Hasler, who has been for some years employed upon a survey of the Coast of the United States, called upon me this Morning, and gave me an Account somewhat in detail of his proceedings. It appears that in consequence of the dissatisfaction at the proceedings under the Ghent Treaty Commissions the discontent has extended to this survey, and an act of Congress has passed the operation of which is supposed by some to suspend it. Mr Hasler says however that he has given such explanations as have been satisfactory to the Senate, and his work will be permitted to go on. A young man named Holbrook, brought me a Letter of Introduction from Dr Ingalls of Boston— He is a native of Charleston South Carolina; has resided some time at Wrentham, Massachusetts, has been attending the medical lectures at the University of Philadelphia, and is now going to pursue his medical studies at Edinburgh, and at London. He is going next week, to Baltimore, and thence by water to Charleston; there to embark for Liverpool whence he goes first to Scotland, and next year to London— He wants Letters of Recommendation which I promised to give him. General P. B. Porter called again about his Accounts, and an advance of money which he wanted. I went with him in his Carriage, and he sat me down at the President’s. There had been appointed a meeting of the members from the delegations of the New England States, in both Houses, at eleven O’Clock this Morning to consult upon the proposal to be made to the British Government in relation to the fisheries. Several of them came, but observing that their attendance was then necessary in Congress, perhaps even to make a Quorum of the House of Representatives, the meeting was adjourned to seven in the Evening. Genl. P. B. Porter was despatched with his order for ten thousand dollars upon the Treasury on Account. At seven in this Evening the meeting was held again at the President’s, and much Conversation upon the proposal to be made; but nothing definitively agreed upon. Mrs Adams went and passed the Evening at her Sister Boyd’s— I walked home from the President’s.

17. VI: I omitted calling this day at the President’s. George Washington Campbell of Tennessee was nominated the day before yesterday, by the President to the Senate, as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Russia and was immediately, and unanimously confirmed by the Senate. He called at the Office this morning to make various enquiries for information necessary for him in relation to his mission. I gave him all that was in my power, and offered him any thing further for which he may have occasion. General Bloomfield called also at the Office; to speak of the Consular Office at Cadiz, from when his nephew is about to return— Mr Silsbee came, upon his claim for the Algerine money. The President had directed that the remainder of the sum 8000 dollars should be deposited in the Branch Bank, to be recovered by an amicable suit in the proportions due to the respective claimants, and that the Attorney General should be directed to give any aid in his power to finish the business. Mr Silsbee said he should have been well satisfied if this course had been taken from the beginning; but a man named Smith, of Philadelphia, has already obtained two thousand dollars of the money; and it would be extremely hard now, if the claimants who were fairly entitled to the whole, must be put to the expense and delays of a lawsuit to obtain the remaining four fifths of their due— He said Commodore Decatur would testify that the Brig Edwin and her Cargo, were the only property intended to be provided for, by the 10.000 stipulated to be paid, by the Dey of Algiers in the Algerine Treaty, and in order at once to finish the business, he offered to give a discharge in full for himself and his fellow claimants upon payment of the 8000 dollars remaining. I promised to state these circumstances to the President, and take his further directions on the subject— I attempted to write this Evening but without success.

18. V:30.Mr Holbrook called again at my house, but I was not ready for him with the promised Letters. At the President’s; he consented to the arrangement proposed by Silsbee, with regard to his claim, upon the Algerine money. Silsbee came to the Office with Decatur, who certified on the back of Silsbee’s claim, that the Brig Edwin & Cargo, was the only property for which the money at Algiers had been paid, and Silsbee signed for himself and his associate claimants a discharge in full, upon which I gave him an order for the remaining 8000 dollars. Mr N. Pope called also with a claim of the Marshal of the Illinois Territory, which I could not settle. Received an important despatch N. 60.
from G. W. Erving, which I sent over to the President. Dined with Mrs Adams and spent the Evening at Mr Hyde de Neuville’s. The party at dinner were about 20. and a numerous company in the Evening.

19. V:45. I attended Church at the Hall of the House of Representatives and heard Mr Allison one of the Chaplains of Congress. House very thin— His Sermon was a sort of answer, very feeble to the discourses of Mr Holley— After Church I returned visits of Mr Dana, and Mr Simkins of South Carolina. Called at Heronimus’s to see General Izard, but he was gone to Baltimore—Mrs Adams spent the Evening at Mr Middleton’s at Georgetown.

20. VI:45.General S. Smith of Baltimore, Mr Trimble and Mr N. Pope came and took leave of us. When I called at the President’s he said he should go to the Hall of Congress to sign the Bills which at the last day of the Session, were very numerous, and it was usual for the heads of Departments to be there with the President; he therefore asked me to meet him there at four O’Clock; and to mention it to the Secretaries of War and the Navy, whose Offices are in the same building with mine— I accordingly saw Mr Calhoun; but Mr Crowninshield was ill; confined to his bed at his lodgings. Mr G. W. Campbell called at the Office and made many enquiries relating to his mission to Russia— I went home and thence at four O’Clock to the Hall of Congress. The President was in the Committee-Room of the Senate. His brother and Secretary Joseph Jones Monroe, Mr Crawford, the Secretary of the Treasury, and James Barbour a Senator from Virginia were with him; examining the enrolled Bills, ready for his signature. Mr Calhoun, the Secretary of War came in afterwards. About forty Bills were examined and signed. Mr J. J. Monroe occasionally went in to each House, and announced his having signed Bills, to the house where they originated. Between eight and nine O’Clock, a Committee of two Members from each house; Mr Macon and Mr King of the Senate, Mr Pitkin and General Harrison of the House of Representatives came and announced, Mr Macon speaking, that that they were ready to adjourn, if the President had no further Communications to make. He said he had none, and the two Houses immediately afterwards adjourned— As I was walking home, Mr King overtook me, and immediately after we met his Carriage— He took me to my own door— He told me the President had communicated to him, the despatch last received from G. W. Erving; and expressed sentiments on the subject entirely congenial with my own. I came home to dine alone about nine in the Evening— Mrs Adams spent the Evening with her sister Boyd, who had a Son, born last Friday.

21. VII: Attended the Office without calling at the President’s. There was a square of land in the City sold at Auction this morning, N. 231. I requested Mr R. Forrest to attend and make the purchase for me; if it should be sold at a reasonable price— But it was bid off against him by Mr James Greenleaf at 8 1/2 Cents a foot. There was about an acre and a quarter. Mr Martinez Pizarro called this morning at my house, from Mr Onis, to say that he should go to-morrow, and offering to take despatches for Mr Erving— I sent him four packets, in the course of the day. Mr Lowndes called, and returned me a note from Mr De Neuville, which I sent him last Saturday— Mr Jeremiah Nelson also called to make some further enquiries concerning the fisheries— Mrs Adams spent the Evening at her Sister, Mrs: Frye’s. I wrote the draft of a Note to Mr Onis, on the case of W. D. Robinson— The adjournment of Congress takes off the excessive pressure of public business; and I dread the danger of relaxing into pernicious idleness. Now is the time when every moment may be employed profitably to the public interest— And may it not be neglected.

22. VI: Met at the President’s this Morning Mr Cruger, a member of the house of Representatives from the State of New-York— Most of the members are already gone. I received Letters from Mr John Vaughan, and J. E. Hall of Philadelphia, informing me that I have been elected a member of the American Philosophical Society. Mr James Greenleaf sent to make me an offer of half the Square which he purchased yesterday; at the price he gave for it: which I declined— I called at the Office of Mr Tucker the Treasurer and received by a warrant from the Navy Office, fifty dollars being the remainder of one hundred dollars due me by John Cook, a Chaplain in the Navy, for money which I lent him nearly two years ago in England— Mrs Adams spent the Evening at her Sister Boyd’s. I made a draft of a Proclamation, concerning Plaster of Paris— There was a sharp frost last Night— My thermometer this morning stood, after Sunrise at 28.

23. VI:30. St. George’s day. Upon which I purposely dated the Plaster of Paris Proclamation, one of the most significant acts, though upon a very insignificant subject, that the Government of the United States will have issued, since the Declaration of Independence— I drafted this Proclamation, as a proposal to the President, without any previous Communication with him of my ideas concerning it— I read the Draft to him this Morning without any comment— He made no remark upon it, but asked me to leave it with him, that he
might read it over again, before he should conclude to sign it— I left it with him, requesting him that it might bear date this day, as its operation commences from the date, and ought not to be delayed— But without telling him that I wished it to be dated on St. George’s day. He sent it to me, in the course of the day, approving it without the alteration of a word— It is a curious speculation in my mind, whether it will be felt and noticed, here, in Nova-Scotia, or in England—or whether it will pass unobserved as an ordinary proclamation— The point of the date, is one of those recondite mysteries which no human being will understand without an explanation— The operation of our Plaster Law, was purposely made to commence on the fourth of July— This every body understands— Its termination upon St. Georges day will pass unperceived— Mr Hasler called this morning and kept me about two hours, on the subject of his removal from the survey of the Coast, and his appointment as Astronomer, to the Commission under the 5th. Article of the Ghent Treaty— He called afterwards at the Office. Young Fenwick also came to renew a solicitation for one of the two new Clerkships in the Department; but all the Clerks who are already in the Department are so extremely adverse to his admission that I shall be obliged to reject him— I dined this day at Mr Bagot’s with a diplomatic Company— The foreign Ministers and their parties were all in full court dresses— Mr Campbell, and myself were the only Americans there. The party broke up before nine.

24. V:30.Mr James Greenleaf called at my house, and I walked with him over the Tyber and viewed two Squares which he with Mr Saml. Eliot junr. offers me for sale— At half past eleven there was a meeting of the Commissioners of the sinking fund at the Treasury Office. Mr Gaillard the President pro Tempore of the Senate was there, and Mr Crawford. It was resolved to pay off this year, one half the Louisiana Stock, and to suspend all other purchases of Stocks. Mr Hassler called again at my Office; and Mr Hawkins the agent under the 6th. and 7th. Articles of the Ghent Treaty. Received, despatches from Mr Russell at Stockholm; from Messrs.Rodney, Graham and Bland at Rio Janeiro, and from Mr Sumter, who asks to be recalled— I left all these despatches at the Presidents— He had rode out on horseback— We had a tea, and Evening party at home. Music, by Mr Ten Cate, and Madame de Heredia. I played Chess with Mr Baker.

25. VI: At the President’s— He had read over only part of the papers received yesterday from Buenos Ayres. At the Office, I had successively, Coll. Reuben Kemper, Mr J. M. Baker, Coll. Hawkins and Mr Hassler— I had examined Kemper’s accounts, which the 5th. Auditor, Pleasonton, had declined passing, and in general I saw no reason for being of a different opinion. Kemper said he wished to see the President on the subject, and to have me present, when he sees him— I told him I would mention to the President, his request. Hawkins wants further instructions as agent to the Commission under the 6th. and 7th. Articles of the Treaty. And Mr Hassler is to be sent as the Astronomer to the Commission under the 5th. Article— Mr Baker came as usual to solicit an Office, and brought a new Letter of Recommendation from Mr Jefferson— These Gentlemen occupied almost the whole time that I was at the Office. As I was coming home a young man namedmet me, and told me he was soliciting the Office of Secretary of Legation to go to Russia with Mr Campbell— He had been to him, and Mr Campbell had told him he must have a Secretary acquainted with the French language. He was coming therefore with Mr Forsyth to ask me how much French, it was necessary for the Secretary to know, and whether, having been himself educated at the Jesuit’s College at Baltimore, where he had learnt some French, he could not by two or three Months of Study acquire a competency to be a Secretary of Legation— I had seen this man last Sunday at Mr Dana’s chamber. I wrote this morning to Messrs.Greenleaf and Eliot making them an offer, for the two Squares, which they declined accepting. Mr Cutts sent me word by Mr R. Forrest that he had some Squares to dispose of, very suitable for building, which he would let me have at a very moderate price. Commodore Decatur made similar proposals to Mrs Adams last Evening. My wife has been all this day very ill, and confined to her bed— This Evening she sent for Dr Hunt. The President appointed Monday, one O’Clock to receive Mr Correa de Serra, the Portuguese Minister.

26. VI.My wife had a bad night, and was still confined almost the whole of this day to her bed. Towards Evening however, she was better— Dr Hunt was here this Morning— I got engaged in an accidental examination of my own private affairs, which absorbed my attention until 3. afternoon, when I took a walk of an hour and a half— The Sun was almost at Summer heat— I find in examining the state of my account Books, that since February 1815, my day-book has been entirely neglected; in consequence of which my affairs are getting into a state of dangerous confusion— I began the attempt to retrieve the arrears of my Day-Book— But it takes time which I can ill spare from the public business.

27. V:45.Mr Ten Cate the Charge d’Affaires of the Netherlands called here this Morning— Also Dr Hunt. I called at Mr Correa de Serra, the Portuguese Minister’s lodgings, at Heronimus’s; and at One O’Clock met him at the President’s; of whom he had an Audience to deliver a Letter from the King of Portugal, to the United States, announcing the Marriage of his Son to an Austrian Archduchess— The Abbé was dressed like ourselves, and not in the full Court Suit— He has been highly hypocondriac, and fancying himself extremely ill went off suddenly some six weeks ago, first to Baltimore, and thence to Norfolk, to consult a Portuguese physician. He has come back as suddenly as he went, and is going again shortly to Philadelphia. His official and ceremonial audience was very short; but he remained afterwards conversing upwards of half an hour, with much good humour and brilliancy. His conversation is delightful and sparkling with wit. The President told me that he should leave the City to-morrow for an excursion of two or three days to a farm that he owns about thirty miles distant— I received despatches from Mr Rush, and from Mr Pinkney at St. Petersburg. I called upon Mr Cutts to talk about his land and to recommend S. B. Goddard to him as a Clerk— I had spoken to the President about young Fenwick, who has been earnestly soliciting for a clerkship in my Office; but who is extremely obnoxious to the Clerk, already there; and most especially to Mr Purviance— I saw the President was embarrassed, for Fenwick himself had been with him to ask his influence in his favour; and Purviance had been to engage his influence against him— The President therefore determined to take no part in the affair, but observed a strict neutrality— After dinner this Evening, I rode down with my wife to the river, to view a Square recommended to us for building, by Commodore Decatur— Remainder of the Eve, writing— Philip Scheihing’sfather and mother here.

28. V:15. Received while at Breakfast this Morning a Note from the President, appointing a Cabinet Meeting at eleven O’Clock to consider of Instructions to be given to Coll. Hawkins, the Agent to the Commission under the 5th. and 6th. Articles of the Treaty of Ghent. I attended at the time appointed; Crawford, Calhoun and Wirt were there. Crowinshield is confined at home by sickness— The question concerning the Instructions to be given to Hawkins was discussed. This Gentleman who is the Agent of the United States before the Commission under the 6th: and 7th. Articles of the Treaty of Ghent has given such a Construction to the Treaty as would take the whole business from the Commissioners and place it in the Agents— Although he has been repeatedly informed that the President is not of that opinion, he perseveres in his own, and has now called for explicit Instructions. The opinion of the meeting this day was unanimous, that the power of decision belonged to the Commissioners, and that they have the right of executing the duty in such manner as they think proper— Crawford insisted that in that Commission there was no need of Agents, and hinted that it was an oversight in the Treaty to have allowed any Agents. In this opinion however he was alone. Mr Wirt appeared to think more about his Salary, or what he called bread and meat for his children, than of any other Subject. There was a Bill before Congress at the close of the late Session, of Congress for increasing the Salaries of all the heads of Departments— It passed through both houses, but fell through by a disagreement between them upon the details— Mr Wirt wrote sometime since to the President, urging him to recommend to Congress an increase of Salary for the Attorney General; and a Clerk, to be allowed him; and an Office, and various other comforts and conveniences— The President asked Mr Crawford and me, whether we thought he ought to make a recommendation by special message for this increase of Salary which he said must of course include all the Heads of Departments— We both agreed that he ought not That any measure of Congress for that purpose should be spontaneous on the part of Congress— Wirt however is much dissatisfied, and gave some hints of resigning— He has a large family, and cannot hold the Office of Attorney General, without a sacrifice of private practice, for which the salary cannot compensate. I think he will not hold the place long, and although he has opinions and prejudices, not very appropriate to an
Attorney General of the United States, the President would not easily fill his place. He has two faults which may have an ill influence in the affairs of this Nation— An excessive leaning to State Supremacy, and to popular humours. He asked me to negotiate an arrangement this day with the State of Pennsylvania, about a delinquent debtor both to the United States, and the State of Pennsylvania— The United States Marshal took his property in Execution; and the Pennsylvania Sheriff took it from the Marshal— The question was now he said before the Supreme Court, and he was afraid the decision would be in favour of the United States. Pennsylvania was indignant at being summoned before the Court, and refused to appear. I asked him what the Department of State had to do with the affair. He did not know— As a delinquent debtor, I said his case belonged to the Treasury Department— He replied that the Treasury could not relinquish the debt— Nor said I can the Department of State— He said, if the decision should be in favour of the United States, it would certainly stir up a dust—which I told him we could not help— At the Office, I had visitors, Mr Hassler, Dana, the Senator from Connecticut, Rhea, member H.R. from Tennessee, W. Lee, and Peters with a Letter of Recommendation from our Consul at Bordeaux Mr Strobel; Levy, soliciting the Consulate, at St. Thomas’s, and Calhoun the Secretary at War— I gave Hassler his Instructions, and a Letter to C. P. Van Ness the Commissioner; under the 5th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent; and enjoined upon him the utmost possible despatch. Rhea came to take leave. Dana to talk about Headlands, maritime Jurisdiction and combined commercial armaments. The President left the City this afternoon, upon his excursion to his farm— He expects to be back next Saturday or Sunday. In case of necessity he directed me to send him an express. I employed the Evening with more labour than profit.

29. V:30.Mr James Greenleaf called this morning at my house, and I gave him the answer to the equivocal personage calling himself Joseph Antinori Duke of Brindisi; and also his own papers, concerning the two Squares which he and S. Eliot junr. have offered to sell me, but about the price of which we have differed, He goes for Philadelphia to-morrow Morning. He came this Morning from Alexandria, and says P. Hagner has given S. B. Goddard the Clerkship that I solicited for him. At the Office, a Captain William Austin brought me a Letter from Mr W. Gray of Boston. He was Captain of a Privateer during the late War, and since, of an India ship. He has just returned from a Voyage to India, and is very shortly going upon another up the red Sea. He says he thinks the British will not continue the Convention admitting us to trade with their Possessions in India, but that other resources may be opened to us, by establishing factories of our own, and trading with the Natives. Mr Hassler came and took leave. He is to go to-morrow Morning. Mr Peabody the Auctioneer came and delivered me the deed of Lots 19 and 20. in Square, N. 231. from F. S. Key. I give four Cents a foot for them; and five dollars for the Deed; for Peabody says ‘tis customary here to pay for the Deed, buyer and Seller, half and half. There are 8747 Square feet in the two Lots: but the length and depth of the Lots is not laid down in the Deed. Peabody promised to bring them to me. When I came home to dinner I found waiting in a Carriage at the gate a Mr De Forrest, just from Buenos-Ayres—who delivered to me despatches from the Commissioners Rodney, Graham & Bland, dated 4. March at Buenos-Ayres where they had just arrived. Mr De Forrest had also a Letter from the Supreme Director Pueyrredon for the President, who I told him was out of town; but would return in three or four days. He asked me, if I should open the Director’s Letter before the President’s return. I said no. He said that after the President should have received it, he should wish to call on me— That he had an appointment as Consul General, from the Supreme Director, which was announced in the Letter— Among the Letters which he delivered to me was also one from J. B. Prevost at San Iago de Chile dated February— Mrs Adams passed the Evening at her Sister Boyd’s. Mrs Hellen goes to-morrow upon a tour to Philadelphia, and elsewhere, for the summer— I continued engaged upon the project of bringing up the arrears in my Day-Book they are from 9. February 1815.

30. V:30. On my way this Morning to my Office I met Mr Hyde de Neuville, the French Minister, who expressed much anxiety and alarm, at the Frenchmen, landed at Galvezton under the two L’Allemand’s and was much afraid that there were Buonaparte’s concerned in the affair— I referred him again to Mr Onis for information, but he says Onis protests he knows nothing about it— He admitted however that Onis had tampered with Galabert— Had given him money and perhaps a Letter to the Vice-Roy of Mexico but he employed him only as a Spy— But there was a great force, coming to join these people from Europe— The despatches that he received from Europe all spoke of it with great anxiety; and that was the great cause of the earnestness with which they urged that our differences with Spain may be settled. This led to various remarks and replies, in which he manifested the wish that Spain should cede the Florida’s to us, for a sum of Money; that we should leave the Western Boundary of Louisiana unsettled, and that we should give up the claim for French Spoliations within Spanish Jurisdiction— All this I assured him was out of the question. At the Office I had a visit from Mr Bagot, who also spoke as if alarmed at the L’Allemand expedition to Galvezton and said if there was a Buonaparte concerned in it, his Government would of course consider it as deserving high attention. I referred him to M’Gregor’s expedition, not yet abandoned; to the numbers of people coming out from England to join it— To the popular disposition in England, favouring the cause of the South-Americans, and to the increasing energy of that Sentiment— He has no despatches from England later than January— The February Packet from Falmouth put back six times, and finally sailed in company with that of March, which has arrived by the way of Halifax; while the other coming by the way of Bermuda is not yet here. All his despatches for two Months, are on board— He spoke of several objects concerning which he has written Notes, and as yet received no Answer— The Act for returning extra-duties levied after 3. July 1815. The Proclamation about the militia-man in Georgia, and the money deposited in one of the New-York judicial districts, which is withheld from the owner, because it was adjudicated by the Court for the other district— I told him how all these cases stood— We had also some slight conversation, upon the subject of Colonial policy; upon which he is confident that Great-Britain will not yield— My wife spent the Evening with her Sister Boyd— Mrs Hellen went off this morning upon her traveling tour— Mr Boyd goes with her to Philadelphia. I was again engaged most of the Evening upon my Account Books.

Day. The only change in the distribution of my time since the last Month has been effected by the adjournment of Congress. Since which, I should have some leisure, but for the arrangement of my accounts, the necessity of which was accidentally brought to my attention; and which I find a work of very considerable labour. I have in one shape or another preserved minutes and vouchers which enable me to resume and preserve the thread of all my pecuniary transactions, but it is doubtful whether I shall ever be able to bring them into perfect order, in the shape of accounts. The Great difficulty is of the charges which belong to several different accounts, and those which may at option be set down to any one of several. It often happens that the proper account to which a charge should be set down depends upon that to which a preceding charge made perhaps years before, was set down: and that may be forgotten— Thus the Accounts of Stock, Cash, Interest, Profit and Loss, family expences, Exchange, and the like often run into one another and introduce perplexity and confusion. I have often wondered how Merchants in extensive business, and still more, how the Treasuries of Nations, can keep any regular Accounts when mine, so simple, and so trifling in amount get into a confusion from which I cannot extricate them— There is however no confusion or embarrassment in the present state of my Affairs.
